text: The book does a decent job of relating the concept of Ikigai to modern day psychology (with Frankl's Logotherapy from Man's Search for Meaning among others) and a few scientific references in a simple manner. It talks about how purpose plays an important role in a man's life and the different ways in which it manifests itself. It also tackles some ways to 'find your flow' and ensure that what you do receives 100% of your attention and that you enjoy whatever you are creating.The book also discusses certain other Japanese concepts like takumi (specialized workers) and moai (connections with community or friend-circle). The brief discussions have the benefit of being to the point and simple but also pose the risk of trivializing them into regular self-help advice. The book also delves into Japanese perspectives on living life and persevering without getting caught up in artificially-created urgency. But again, maybe the authors wished for the readers to research more or meditate more on the content given the concise treatment of the same.The chapters on diet and exercises have more details and thus, may be more useful. Certain foods are dealt with in greater detail as is the concept of 'hara hachi bu' wherein one eats only 80% of what would actually assuage his hunger. The chapter on exercises includes illustrations and steps. While they may suffice for some of the purposes mentioned in the book - the philosophy behind them, progressive increments and other essential details are missing or insufficient.I was interested in the concept of Ikigai and wanted to read more about it. Despite being well-written and presenting modern applications, the book did not fulfill my requirements at all. Some of the condensed content made me think that the extended research, including on-site interviews, done by the authors for writing this book was clearly lost in translation or presentation in certain parts.The hardcover is pretty and soothing with its matte texture. Inner pages are smooth and heavy with a cream tinge. The font size is good. The spine as well as pages hold up well. Overall, the book is quite light and sturdy. Bought it for INR 460 against MRP of INR 499.

text: The title of the book suggests that it is unravelling The Japanese Secrets to a Long and Happy Life, but it also does incorporate the key elements from Indian way of life i.e.Yoga and the Chinese way of life i.e. Tai Chi. Indeed the key point that emerges from the book is that one should keep on moving and not spend most of the time of the day either sitting or lying down.It also dispels the notion that one should start withdrawing from the activities after one is officially retired and advocated that staying active is what would be the deciding factor if one aspires to complete a century on this planet- which incidentally is a Japanese quote from where the book starts. Does it not seem so pertinent in the times that we are living in- the Corona times. IKIGAI actually means living a meaningful life. Though Japan is a major rice growing country, the book advocates drawing from the patterns of food from people residing in Okinawa in Japan is that the food plate construct on a daily basis should be dominated by vegetables and Tofu,  and there is a particular emphasis on the size of the plate. The plate should not be large, as we normally have in Indian conditions but it should be of medium size.However  one may be hungry, one should aspire to eat 80% only which is called as Hara hachi bu in Japanese and were we to follow the maxim it would take care of quite a lot of health related issues that we are confronted with, associated with over eating.Interestingly enough Japanese have been practising the concept of saving called as Moai-where farmers get together to share best practices and also help one another with meager harvests. In the times of distress that the farming community is in the country, can we aspire to have such kind of a group of farmers. Farmers Producers Organizations have been formed but they need to converge to the concept of Moai to make it really effective.This group also had the provision of a monthly contribution akin the idea of SELF HELP GROUPS with a difference that the contribution is utilised for social activities and left over from the contribution is given a member based on his requirements.The book has tried to assimilate other such initiatives from around the world but the bottom line is that one has to find flow in everything that one is doing.  There should not be any distraction or multi-tasking at all as it does not help anyway. To attain the flow, the authors have requested to adopt the policy of leaving the cell phones one hour before going to sleep, and one hour after getting up. Tough act to adopt? Each one of us has a passion inside us or the Ikigai and if we have found it we need to practice and fine tune it, and if not yet, it is incumbent upon us to discover it.NALIN RAI

text: What is the one thing that we have in common? It is that we all are searching for Meaning....Ikigai will not only help you in finding the meaning of your life but will also inspire you in the most unique way! What makes it unique? The authors have not only presented their thoughts but they have put together interviews of the true masters.  Right from Logotherapy to Radio Taiso, readers are provided with ways and techniques to deal with different scenarios of life and live it in a better way. Read through the case studies ranging from the German Concentration Camp to the life histories of Bill Gates and Einstein. Know how the masters of different fields discovered their Ikigai and find yours! This book has positively in every page, inspiration in every sentence and comfort in every word. I would highly recommend this one to you all! üå∏üìò
title: A peaceful and motivating read!

text: Our ikigai is different for all of us, but one thing we have in common is that we are all searching for meaning.‚Äù‚Äï Hector Garcia PuigcerverThe word 'IKIGAI' is a Japanese concept which means "a reason for being". It refers that one must have a purpose in life which will make their life worthwhile, and for this one must take some willing actions to feel satisfied and have some meaning to life.This book mainly tells that every single person has their own ikigai. Every person finds an ikigai at a certain point of life. Our ikigai is different from others and is hidden deep inside us. Once a person discovers his or her ikigai, it brings meaning to their lives. It is not like that a person has no meaning of living. The books  notifies various methods using which a person can find their purpose in life. A person can find their purpose by doing different activities till they don't feel cheerful and pleased doing it.So far as liking this book, it was good. It had some motivational lessons to improve our lives. Also had some ways following which one could refine lives. But the way it was written did not have much impact on me as every chapter till the end had same things repeated in different ways. It is a bit overrated!
title: Disappointing

text: I have always wondered about the Japanese spirit of resilience and rebirth. How do they live so long? How are they so productive to the end of their days? How do they have such excellent physiques? Most importantly, what gives them the tenacity to never give up even in the face of the most extreme odds (the aftermath of the WW2 being an example, out of which the Japanese only came out stronger)?The answer is in this book, and it is Ikigai.Ikigai doesn't just preach; it peppers itself with several examples and anecdotes, including tips from the supercentenarians of the world (those who have lived beyond 110 years). It gives thorough advice on enriching various aspects of life.I strongly recommend this book to all of us who are still looking for meaning in our lives, who feel that life is out to get them at every moment, who are, simply, too overwhelmed by everything that's going on around. Do pause awhile, and immerse yourself in this world of Ikigai and you'll come out richer.And, since I heard the audiobook on Audible, I'd put a word of recommendation for that too. Brilliantly narrated, with the right pauses and inflections and the calls to action.
title: Will Help You Rediscover Your Purpose in Life. Strongly Recommended.

text: I love the concept of this book but I understood it in the first twenty pages. What follows seemed like a diversion. For me, ikigai is the driving purpose of my life. It keeps me motivated and happy and somehow the book shifted from a happy purposeful life, to a long life which I did not really like. Focus was having a long life with happy being implied, while I would have preferred it to be the reverse. The book is good but did not live upto to my expectations. Also, I felt that the methods and habits are not always feasible for urban people which should have been considered in the book. It felt like a collection of interview excerpts. The cover is beautiful and soothing but in my opinion the book is good for beginners. It did not live upto the hype around it and yet again I felt that I should never read hyped books.

text: The negative reviewers seem to have largely missed the point. Or to have been looking for something they will not find in a book. Yes there are chapters on diet and exercise, and the content of these is not particularly new or surprising (however irritating it may be, these things are indeed features of a healthy lifestyle).But there is a good deal more, including the sense of purpose and meaning that is common to those who have lived to an advanced age. The way this is explored and its links to, for example, logotherapy, are helpful and illuminating. Ikigai offers a genuine recipe for living a meaningful life if you are prepared to give it some time and thought.I strongly disagree with the reviewer who wanted it to be much longer! Most books are badly overwritten and in need of editing: the value of a book is in the quality of its content, not the number of pages it fills. This one is attractively presented, says what it needs to, then stops.

text: If you've read Freakonomics, you'll see why.When talking about life expectancy authors rely heavily on interviews with long-living individuals to deduct the factors that contribute to their ability to live long. This is simply irrelevant. If you ask an average tall person, why they are tall, they would not be able to answer, and their ideas and intuition would be as good as yours.Authors have a very noble goal of finding the factors that increase one's life expectancy, but they do so without use of statistical analysis and or scientific methods often leading to humorous contradictions.Here's one example: "during last 100 years, life expectancy increased in average 0.3 years per year". "Cavemen had much less stress than modern humans, since volumes of information and devices are contributing to the stress". But why is then life expectancy growing proportionally to the development of media then? Maybe this informational stress *positively* correlates with life expectancy? Without proper research it is impossible to tell if values are correlated and if they have any reason-cause relations.I liked a chapter about author's experience in Ogimi in Okinawa was nevertheless very good. Not because the insights were valuable, but because of a vivid image of traditional Japan that authors have conveyed. This is the most authentic chapter and it deserves a separate book. I would read that book, not this one.Authors jump between subjects of mental health, having purpose in life, diet and exercise, compiling and reciting many other great books. From this perspective, the book was very valuable, since I learned about works of Nassim Nicholas Taleb and Viktor Frankl. I already knew about Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi and planned to read his book "Flow".Doing my own research on what authors have briefly mentioned I discovered several other areas of knowledge that I want to learn more about. This was the biggest value of this book.Lastly, authors start to jump over myriad of loosely-related subjects: diet and nutritions, meditation, spiritual practices, yoga, tai chi, and it all in just few words. text: I am a non-Japanese person who has lived in Japan for over 3 years, and was interested in this mystical concept of "ikigai". So, I thought I would start with this well-reviewed book.Despite it's title and introduction, this book touches very little on ikigai, and instead focuses on "how to live a long time" based on poorly researched information (the Daily Mirror said fruits are healthy, who knew!!!) and random, biased accounts of different forms of therapy, asian philosophy, and even *Chinese* tai-chi. The authors had the rare opportunity to gain insight into the lives of the Okinawan centenarians, but sadly only came away with little more than a few quotes about how much the elders love to garden and hang out with their friends.After reading this book, I thought I ask a real Japanese about ikigai, so I asked a native friend. I was told it is basically a lifelong hobby, passion, or profession. Sorry to burst anyone's bubble, but this is just another poorly researched and biased piece of literature romanticizing asian and "eastern" cultures and won't really provide you with constructive information.

text: I loved the concept of IKIGAI when I first saw the diagram, and bought this book because I imagined it would help me through the process of mapping out and defining my IKIGAI. A kind of step-by-step guide to discovering my IKIGAI. It isn't that. About halfway through the book I realised it wasn't going to provide that level of insight and 'instruction', and initially felt disappointed. I stopped reading and decided to re-read the book for what it is, rather than from the perspective of what I expected it to be, and I discovered a wonderful book I definitely recommend for other seekers.It's filled with some great insights, brief introductions to other great philosophies, and a high-level overview of the 'territory' that includes IKIGAI. If you're looking for a detailed map with precise instructions on how to go from 'here' to 'there', this book is not going to be that for you. It is, instead, a very broad guide that points in the general direction of IKIGAI, and gives you some other IKIGAI-related nuggets of wisdom for consideration and inspiration.If you're feeling something tugging inside of you, this is a great place to start. If you're being pulled strongly in a specific direction and are seeking a comprehensive guide through the mist, this book may frustrate you rather than help you.

text: The rather exotic sounding name of this book, ikigai, as the authors explain, is relatively straightforward. ‚ÄúThis Japanese concept, which translates roughly as ‚Äúthe happiness of always being busy,‚Äù is, ‚Äúlike logotherapy, but it goes a step beyond.‚Äù Logotherapy, they explain, ‚Äú‚Ä¶helps people find their purpose in life.‚ÄùIt is a good book. My overall rating of the book has little to do with the quality of the writing or the underlying concept. The former is quite good and the latter is valid. My rating is strictly personal and relates more to who might be considering adding it to their reading list. Not a ‚Äúdon‚Äôt,‚Äù for sure. More like, ‚Äúunderstand it for what it is.‚ÄùFor those who are ardent fans of all things philosophical and psychological, as I am, this is a good book that plows relatively little new ground. Finding purpose in life, keeping busy, eating well, and finding connection to the world around you is important. It‚Äôs ground, however, that has been covered by many authors over the years.If you haven‚Äôt sampled of these past triumphs you will enjoy this book very much. It is a great and easily read introduction to the topics of longevity and the benefits of living in the moment. And it chronicles many of the philosophies and prior contributions to the topic, from Buddhism to Stoicism, with a stop at the Serenity Prayer. Eastern, and particularly Japanese, contributions are given extra attention. Wabi-sabi and ichi-go ischi-e, for example, are explained in some detail, but remain an overview. Relatively newer concepts like antifragility are also explained. It even covers the Six Healing Sounds introduced by Sun Simiao in the sixth century. (This one was new to me.)A lot of the book turns on Ogimi, in the Okinawa Prefecture in Japan, which holds the distinction of being the oldest village on the planet. (In that many of the residents have lived very long lives.) It‚Äôs a delightful visit. Having lived in China for nine years and having visited Japan many times over the course of more than three decades, I have a deep fondness for places like Ogimi. I‚Äôm not sure, however, that they aren‚Äôt byproducts of the totality of Japanese culture. Could they take seed in places like California or Virginia, for example?Part of my ikigai is to be a nice person and not think disparagingly of anyone. And I am not here. This book was an interesting read for me, and may be a revelational read for you. I make no judgment on that. I just give you my experience as a reader.This book would, in my opinion, make an excellent gift for anyone in your life that might need a little boost or is otherwise hard to buy for. There is absolutely nothing here that could meet with controversy or resistance. It is decidedly upbeat throughout.And that is saying a lot of good things about any book.
